游戏是好游戏，暴雪也是真的该死

The game is good. There definitely are many ups and downs with this game, like the predatory monetisation or poor balancing at times, for sure. However, the same can be said to literally every other game too. Despite what the internet will tell you; No, Team 4 who are responsible for Overwatch, are a completely separate party from the higher ups at Activision Blizzard that actually committed all the sexual crimes. Stop acting as if the only reason why the game is in a bad state (in some peoples' eyes) is because of this misunderstanding. There are hardworking game developers and artists putting all their love and care into this game, only to have their hard work undermined by the past actions of these shitty executives.

Fuck Bobby Kotick and Mike Yberra. 

I understand that it's trendy to hate on Blizzard nowadays but don't just blindly listen to the hate bandwagon and instead, form your own opinions about this game. I have fun with this game and many others will agree (or agree to disagree) with me too. Who knows, maybe if you try the game, you might have fun! Or not. I'm not here to tell you how to feel. All I would ask is to keep an open mind before you pass any kind of judgement.

The only people who are calling this game bad are people who have been genuinely burned by this game and have genuine criticism against it (which is completely fair and understandable), or bitter old Tf2 players who created the whole "Tf2 vs OW2" argument in their own minds as a way to distract them from their own sinking ship of a game. No, Tf2 did not outlive OW2. And no, OW 6v6 is not better than 5v5, grow up. As a former Tf2 player who moved to OW when it came out, I would have loved to see both of these extremely similar communities to co-exist alongside one another. This comes from a place of love when I say that I am extremely disheartened by this one sided hate towards OW. If you believe that Tf2 is the better game, good for you. I can't change your mind and I don't plan to. All I ask, again, is for the TF2 community to keep an open mind.

If you still have some deep-rooted hatred for OW but you don't exactly know why, please just go outside. Discover a new hobby, talk to someone, or just do anything that is actually productive. Life is too short to be blindly hating on what people like. Just let people enjoy what they want.

这次差评，给的真他妈的爽！

Overwatch, Blizzard Entertainment’s foray into the first-person shooter (FPS) genre, promised a refreshing take on team-based combat. With its diverse cast of characters, each boasting unique abilities, the game was poised to redefine how FPS games were played. However, while Overwatch has its merits, there are notable areas where it fails to meet the expectations of its target audience.

1. Predictability of Gameplay:
Overwatch's initial appeal came from its variety of heroes, each bringing different strengths and tactics to the battlefield. However, as the meta solidified, only a handful of heroes became viable in competitive play. This led to repetitive matches where the same strategies were employed over and over. The predictability detracted from the game's potential depth, making it less about innovative strategies and more about mastering a few dominant playstyles.

2. Imbalanced Characters:
Blizzard's attempt to constantly balance the heroes has been a double-edged sword. Some patches swung the pendulum too far, rendering previously dominant characters nearly useless and catapulting others to an overpowered status. This constant flux frustrated players who had dedicated time to mastering specific heroes, only to find their efforts wasted with the next update.

3. Map Design:
While the aesthetics of Overwatch maps are commendable, their functional design leaves much to be desired. Many maps have choke points that heavily favor defensive play, leading to standstills that can be tedious for both teams. Additionally, some maps provide an overwhelming advantage to certain characters, undermining the game's emphasis on adaptability and strategy.

4. Competitive Play Issues:
The game's competitive mode has been plagued with issues since its inception. From unbalanced team matchups to the phenomenon of "smurfing," where experienced players create low-level accounts to dominate newer players, the competitive experience can be more frustrating than rewarding.

5. Monetization Strategies:
Blizzard’s loot box system, while purely cosmetic, has been a point of contention. Players often find themselves receiving duplicate items, and the randomness can be discouraging for those looking for specific skins or emotes. While the game isn't "pay-to-win," the emphasis on microtransactions can detract from the overall experience.

In conclusion, while Overwatch presented a novel approach to the FPS genre with its colorful characters and abilities, it hasn't been without its flaws. The game's predictability, balancing issues, map design, and competitive play challenges prevent it from reaching the heights it once promised. One can only hope that Blizzard addresses these issues in future iterations or updates to recapture the magic that once drew players in.

bastion

[b]Feel free to love the game, but please.. do not spend a penny on it, if you ever played Overwatch 1 you know how amazing that game was and how shitty you have to feel ever since they decided to „upgrade“ our experience with this sequel. [/b]

[h1]What I see as main issues of the current state of Overwatch[/h1]

[h2]Lootboxes vs Season pass[/h2]

Lootboxes have been hated by gamers for a long time so naturally, when I learned that Overwatch will have them, I was sceptical. I can not remember if beta had them, I looked up my old pre-release screenshots and I could not see anyone wearing anything but the base skins so I will assume they only released it when the game came out.
That being said... Overwatch was completely different to what other companies did with loot boxes. Sure, you could buy them, but it was not needed. If you were playing the game, you were getting lootboxes left and right. Duplicates would give you credits and in 2017 Uncle Jeff gave us a pretty good feature, less duplicates!
It's as if Blizzard cared about their players. It was such a good feature and probably the only time where my collection was filling faster than Bobby Kottick’s pockets. In a few months I was getting currency for duplicates again, but it did not matter, at least I had enough of it to buy whatever skins I wanted when they came out. What a user, or rather... player-friendly feature, right?
So how does Season pass compare to loot boxes? If I only had to use one word, it would be “crummy”. I only purchased the very first season pass, which I did not even finish because, let be honest, it takes a quite a long time. What did I get from that season pass? Few lines on heroes I don’t like, Kiriko, which is honestly the only reason why I got the pass to begin with and some other stuff I didn’t even notice. It just didn’t feel rewarding and I’m not sure why. Perhaps it was because I no longer had to patiently wait for that box to open, perhaps I was just expecting more.
I have one big advantage as an old player though, I have 20 thousand credits from the previous game. That is enough for me to get a few awesome skins that I want. How long will it take to a new player, however? No worries, just open your wallet and pay, easy, right? This is why I am personally saying that old system was better, it was less predatory, it was rewarding, and it was fun! 
Where did I get to this conclusion? I recently met a new friend while playing Quick play. We started playing competitive together, but we also played Mystery heroes. It is incredibly easy to spot players who just started playing Overwatch 2 as they have only the basic skins. My friend suddenly said “OMG, do you have legendary skin for like every hero?” I replied... “Yes, not the newest ones tho, didn’t bother with season pass.” That that is what hit me, when I started playing Overwatch I got some decent skins within the first month. Not legendary of course, but it was something to customize my character with. My friend on the other hand, does not have this experience. She either has to buy the Season pass if there is some particular skins that she likes or… well… what is really the other option? Grind the silver coins for years until you have enough to buy that one you so desperately want? That is not the experience I came to OW2 for.

[h2]Newly introduced characters put behind a paywall[/h2]

This is, in my opinion, one of the worst decisions of this game. To put a new hero behind a paywall or some sort of levelling system is ultimately nothing new. One of the games that Overwatch is compared to is Valorant. This comparison, however, completely misses one crucial part. Valorant and Overwatch are not the same game. In Overwatch, you are playing a hero that has abilities that you kill your enemies with, but in Valorant – you buy guns that are the main source of kills. Everyone in Valorant has access to any weapon they desire. That is not the case in Overwatch, as no heroes (excluding abilities like wall-climbing that Shimada brothers and Kiroko use), can access main character spells of other heroes. This fundamental difference is very often omitted from game comparisons.
So, when it comes to new hero being introduced to the game it takes you a long time to unlock. During that time, you cannot play this hero, which could sometimes put your team in disadvantage. Some heroes just counter others, that was, is, and always be the case. We are talking about a PvP game, where hero picks directly influence your team’s chances to kill enemy players and therefore team’s chances to win the game. Isn’t this regarded as pay to win?

[h2]Why is OW2 even a thing?[/h2]

Why a sequel – “Sequels make us nervous.” 
– Jeff Kaplan, 2k19
If I look at the current state of Overwatch, I understand why it would make them feel nervous.

You know what the biggest L for us was? When they announced OW2 I think it is fair to say that most of us got the impression that OW2 would just be sort of an independent upgrade that people could get but they also wouldn’t necessarily have to. This, however, would make no sense because the games have totally different monetization. That would be a big NO NO in today’s money hungry Blizzard approach.
It is so bizarre to me that they can create a beloved franchise, treat it and the community with all the good things and once someone up the ladder realised… oh, this franchise makes a lot of money already, what could we do to minimize the fun the people have for free and add some stuff nobody asked for just to piss off the community for the same of having much better annual sales? Who cares that people will be angry and 2 years later the interest will tank lol. As the old goblin says, Time is money, ain’t it Blizzard?

[h2]What can we do[/h2]

Truthfully? Not much. I personally do not buy any season passes; I know that I will miss out on some awesome rewards, but it is a small price for trying to have some sort of an impact.
I would however let Jeff Kaplan make a point in all of this: 
“You all know what the videogame industry does. You are the most powerful people in the videogame industry, not us. You have more of a say than anybody else.”

-	https://youtu.be/JlcL0ZthzWU?t=2433

My take on this is… let your voice be heard. If you don’t like how the game changed or is about to change - go and complain. We are the ones who keep the game “alive”. I certainly do want Overwatch and its universe to live and prosper, do you?
Do I believe that the community will eventually be heard, and get some sort of… Overwatch Classic? I doubt that. Activision Blizzard has at this point reached its rock bottom and they are no different to the likes of Electronic Arts and such. I used to be Blizzard fanboy, they made good games, they had good services, and its team was always incredibly engaged in trying to deliver the games for the players, not for the investors or whoever they are trying to satisfy with the annual results. This is, unfortunately, no longer the case, all we have right now are sad memories of how good they used to treat its players. One can only hope that something will eventually happen.

Take care everyone and remember…
	The world could always use more heroes.

Overall 7/10

Gameplay :

It's a hero shooter, the bullshit mechanics can get very annoying at times but it's part of the charm and most of the skill expression is around managing the abilities/ultimates correctly. The skill ceiling is pretty damn high despite the "press Q to win" memes. 

Progression :

The Battle Pass is relatively fast to grind with a ton of challenges offered to you, however the whole "spend at least 20-25hours to get the new hero unless you spend money" schtick is very annoying. 

The character unlock grind for newer players is quite bad though but the gameplay loop is satisfying enough to power through it, in my honest opinion.

Microtransactions :

If you don't care about playing dress-up, this is all meaningless to you. They have slowly been buffing the coin gains since the OW2 release and eventually they will strike a balance. 

Sadly there is really not much available on the FPS market at this time aside from Valorant and CSGO. This fills the gap between now and when a new shooter competitor comes into the fray.

Vou positivar minha review só pelas mais de 400 horas de diversão que esse jogo me proporcionou na battle.net.O jogo tem muitos pontos positivos,como belos mapas,muitos personagens únicos e cheios de carisma,uma boa história por trás  e poder proporcionar milhares de horas de diversão.Mas é muito triste ver o estado atual do jogo pela gestão gananciosa  da blizzard
-O passe de batalha é pior que as lootboxes, se você quer uma skin é quase impossível de conseguir sem gastar dinheiro,além das varias microtransações que eles adicionaram onde até as missões da historia são pagas.
- Ao longo dos anos eles repetiram os eventos quase não trazendo novidades relevantes.
-Muitas mudanças feitas nos personagens foram visando apenas a liga de overwatch que é onde eles conseguiam mais dinheiro ,fazendo isso em detrimento dos jogadores casuais. 
-O 2 no titulo podia ser só uma atualização já que eles cancelaram o modo PvE e a progressão de personagem que tinham prometido.
-Se você for novato pode ter que enfrentar uma comunidade tóxica já que a maioria dos jogadores são muito competitivos mesmo em partidas casuais.
Se teve paciência de ler tudo e ainda quiser jogar espero realmente que se divirta poque o jogo é bom,o problema foram as escolhas feitas pela empresa dona dele.
